text: - Hello, and welcome to Community Chats.
I'm Aley Hammer,

and today we're
interviewing Alex Koumaras,
the MD from Leopard Systems.
Alex, Leopard Systems work

with some of Australia's
largest organizations,

including Toll, Australia
Post, Coles, and David Jones,
just to name a few.
So can you start by telling us
a little bit about Leopard Systems

and how you service these
large enterprise customers?
- Thanks Aley for having me here today.
Absolutely.
So where do I begin?
1990 was when Leopard was first founded.
And since that time we've participated

in what was then a fledgling
enterprise mobility business.
Throughout that time, we've delivered

cutting edge solutions
to many of these clients
as the technology has evolved,

and you can imagine many
changes have transpired
over those 32 years.
All of the companies that you mentioned

across postal, transport
logistics, supply chain, and so on
have all been major, and retail,

have been major consumers
of this style of technology.
Their needs have evolved over that time,

and we've serviced them and
many more over that time,

some of which are still
customers to this day.

- [Aley] Well, it's very
impressive that you service
some of Australia's largest companies,
and Alex, why did you make the move
to the cloud a few years back?
- Look, that was an interesting one.
So what we did was start to notice
that many of our customers

were lacking some of the
resources and technical expertise

that they needed to support
some of these complicated

and sophisticated solutions
that we were delivering.
You know, further to that,
they were a big part of their business

but not necessarily their main
line of business, as well.
So what we saw was an opportunity
to assist our customers at that next level
and take on the burden of providing them
a cloud computing solution,
highly secure, obviously,
but also be able to deliver it in a way

as a software as a service,
with our own internal resources

that would ultimately be a
little bit more consistent
over a longer period of time.

And that's definitely
benefited our customers
over that time, not to mention
that the software as a service model
changes that high CapEx expenditure
that customers tended to have previously
into a consumption-based model.
So they were able to factor that
into their budget processes and so on

and provide greater value
for their business over time,

and we're pretty happy that
we're able to do that for them.
- Thanks so much for sharing.

And Alex, what was the
experience migrating across AWS?

And can you share some of
the benefits that it brought

to not only your business,
but your clients, as well?
- Absolutely.
Like the initial cloud migration
was a great experience for us,

and what we knew at the time
was we didn't wanna stop there.

So as traditional
innovators in our industry,
we wanted to reset our thinking
and look at what the next steps were
to take it to that next level,

not just for us, but also
our customers obviously.
In 2019, we literally cleared the deck

and asked all of our
personnel to participate
in an evaluation process

to look at what
technologies were out there.
And luckily for all of us,
AWS had exactly what we were looking for.
So once we pieced together the components
that we required for our specific use case
and our customers' use case,
what we ended up with was effectively

newer microservice server-less
computing-based architecture

that AWS were prime for
going on that journey with us
to that next generation.

But further to that, the
relationship that was already there
was further built on.

You know, AWS personnel and
team members at the time
had a good understanding

of our traditional
monolithic style solution,
and this new-based architecture
allowed us to deliver a new platform

in a quarter of the time
with half the resources
that we would've traditionally expended.

And that was great because
what we were able to do

was output our new system
even more efficiently.
Over and above the new architecture,
security was something
that we had in our minds from day one.

You know, traditionally it
was added to the solutions.

Now, what we started with
was applying a security model
as a baseline for any new implementation

or any new design that
we had moving forward.

AWS truly had the solution
that we were able to implement,
and we've taken that and applied it

to everything that we do
moving forward as well.

- Well, I'm so glad that
you've been able to cut costs

and improve security and run
your business more efficiently.
And Alex, to round off this interview,
what is your vision for Leopard Systems?
Are there any specific technologies
that you think will enhance your offering

and create new revenue
streams for your business?
- Absolutely.
You know, our current development path
is seeing us out to a point

where we replace everything
that we've traditionally done
with our legacy architecture
with the new architecture

that AWS was instrumental
in developing along with us.
You know, it's going to provide

an unsurpassed level of
redundancy, scalability,
security, and deployment options for us.
In amongst all of that,
what we're also looking to insert
is technology that AWS has already proven,

and by that what I mean
is things like big data,
artificial intelligence, machine learning,

and tying that to what
our traditional solutions
have delivered to add huge amount of value
to our customer base.

And you need to understand
that our systems

cater for a portion of
what our customers do,

and where traditionally
they might have been tied
to again a monolithic backend solution,

ours look to push the envelope
and provide modern tools

that they can benefit from
in the immediate term,

rather than having to
wait five or 10 years

to be able to implement
that type of technology.
- Well, I love that you're always looking

for new ways to provide
value to your clients,
and you are always one step ahead.

So Alex, thank you so much
for coming on the show.
If anyone has any questions,

please pop them in the
comments section below
and we'll get back to you.
Thank you so much, Alex.
- Thanks for having me, thank you.
